story:
Once upon a time, in a small village nestled at the foot of a great mountain, lived a kind and devout Muslim father named Rashid and his young son, Hassan. Hassan was a curious and adventurous boy who loved to explore the world around him and ask questions about everything he saw.

One day, Hassan asked his father, "Baba, why do we pray five times a day?"

Rashid smiled at his son and replied, "My dear Hassan, praying five times a day is one of the Five Pillars of Islam. It is a way for us to remember Allah and show our gratitude for all the blessings He has given us. It also helps us to stay focused on our faith and to lead a righteous life."

Hassan nodded, but he still had many questions. "Baba, how do we know when it's time to pray?"

Rashid took his son outside and pointed to the sky. "See those stars, Hassan? The brightest one is called the North Star. When it is directly above us, it is time for us to pray the Fajr prayer, which is the first prayer of the day. As the day goes on, the sun rises and we pray the Dhuhr prayer. Then, the sun begins to set and we pray the Asr prayer. When the sun has completely set, we pray the Maghrib prayer. And finally, when the sky is completely dark, we pray the Isha prayer, which is the last prayer of the day."

Hassan was fascinated. "Baba, can I help you pray?"

Rashid was overjoyed. "Of course, my dear Hassan. I would be honored to pray with you."

So, every day, Hassan and Rashid would pray together, thanking Allah for all the blessings in their lives. And as they prayed, Hassan learned more and more about his faith, growing stronger in his devotion to Allah.

One night, as Hassan lay in bed, he looked up at the stars and thought about all the things he had learned. He felt grateful for his father's patience and guidance and for the opportunity to practice his faith.

As he drifted off to sleep, he heard his father's voice reciting the Quran, the words filling the room with a sense of peace and serenity. And Hassan knew that he was loved and protected, not just by his father, but by Allah, the Most Merciful and Compassionate.

And so, Hassan grew up to be a kind and devout Muslim, just like his father, and he passed down the traditions and values of their faith to his own children and grandchildren. And they all lived happily, ever after, guided by the love of Allah and the wisdom of the Quran.
